title: Giant (starting race)
data:
The **giant** is a playable race that first appears in [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), and is also present in [NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk"), [SliceHack](/wiki/SliceHack "SliceHack"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). Most implementations give them traits similar to the non-playable [giants](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)") encountered in vanilla *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, such as heightened [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") caps, lower speed, and the ability to freely pick up and carry [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder").

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Gather additional info, expand Grunt and Slice in particular, add Hack'EM info"*

[ ]

## Contents

## GruntHack

### Racial benefits and restrictions

The giant's size and thick hide grants them an improved base AC of 6 (compared to 10 for standard vanilla races); they are also capable of lifting boulders, which are treated as completely weightless much like they are for non-player giants and giant polyforms in vanilla *NetHack*. However, they cannot wear body armor of any kind, and are too large to fit through narrow diagonal gaps; fortunately, this means that giants also cannot fall through [trap doors](/wiki/Trap_door "Trap door").

Note that an [encumbrance](/wiki/Encumbrance "Encumbrance") warning may occasionally display when attempting to pick up a boulder, even when using [m](/wiki/M "M") to move over one.

#### Attribute caps

| Character [Race](/wiki/Race "Race") | [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") |
| ----------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Giant                               | 18/\*\*                               | 12                                       | 20                                                | 18                                                | 14                              | 18                                    |

## EvilHack

In EvilHack, the giant is added as a playable race in version 0.1.2, and is adapted and modified from GruntHack and SliceHack.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Giants can be any [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment"), and can be played as a [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel"), [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai"), [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie"), or [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard").

### Racial benefits and restrictions

Player giants have [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") like most non-[human](/wiki/Human "Human") races, more hit points per level than human characters, and gain hungerless [regeneration](/wiki/Regeneration "Regeneration") at experience level 12. However, their movement speed of 10 is markedly slower compared to other races, and they also have an innate [aggravate monster](/wiki/Aggravate_monster "Aggravate monster") property that they cannot override with most forms of [stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth"); the sole exception is being granted the property via successful [prayer](/wiki/Pray "Pray") on their [god](/wiki/God "God")'s [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar").

Giants know the identity of all worthless pieces of glass, and start the game with some random [gems](/wiki/Gems "Gems") identified - they are also capable of using uncursed [touchstones](/wiki/Touchstone "Touchstone") as blessed similar to [gnomes](/wiki/Gnome "Gnome"), and can [dig](/wiki/Dig "Dig") as well as any [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)"). They can also easily pick up and carry boulders, which can additionally be stacked like any other projectile, and weigh 8 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum") for giants as opposed to the standard 6000 aum; [m](/wiki/M "M") can be used to walk over a boulder rather than push it. In [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban"), a giant player will be given a prompt for picking up or moving onto a boulder, and boulder-related penalties are doubled to -2 [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"); this does not apply if you have already solved the level, making each floor a valuable source of powerful projectiles.

As in GruntHack, giant characters in EvilHack have a base AC of 6 due to their size and thick hide. They are immune to [engulfing](/wiki/Engulfing "Engulfing") and falling through trap doors (though they can enter them at will), and can tear through webbing with ease. Their size also incurs extra damage from projectiles fired by [slings](/wiki/Sling "Sling"), and they cannot [ride](/wiki/Ride "Ride") the vast majority of steeds in the game; they also cannot fit through small diagonal spaces or wear the mass majority of body armor, cloaks and shirts - the only exceptions are [chromatic dragon scales](/wiki/Chromatic_dragon_scales_\(EvilHack\) "Chromatic dragon scales (EvilHack)") for any role, and [large splint mail](/wiki/Large_splint_mail "Large splint mail") for giant Samurai. Fortunately, the Sokoban prize armor is tailored so that player characters of all species can use them, including giants.

Giants' size and strength grant additional advantages elsewhere, however: in addition to making strength-based actions easier, giants excel in combat with their [bare hands](/wiki/Bare_hands "Bare hands") and with [clubs](/wiki/Club "Club") - they have a greater chance of stunning an opponent with a club or punch, and can shatter a foe's wielded weapon with almost any wielded weapon of their own. Giants can also wield [two-handed weapons](/wiki/Two-handed_weapon "Two-handed weapon") in one hand, and may even [twoweapon](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") them as well. The [woolly mammoth](/wiki/Woolly_mammoth "Woolly mammoth") is the sole available steed for giants, but is a suitably powerful choice for a pet in its own right, and is capable of steamrolling several late-game monsters.

#### Attribute caps

| Character [Race](/wiki/Race "Race") | [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") |
| ----------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Giant                               | 25                                    | 14                                       | 25                                                | 14                                                | 18                              | 16                                    |

Giants have increased initial and maximum carrying capacity to complement their higher strength and constitution caps - but their movement speed and caps for dexterity, intelligence, and charisma are much lower.

#### Price adjustments

The following price adjustments are used for giant interactions with [racial](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper"):

|       | Shopkeeper's race |     |       |     |                                                            |          |         |                                                          |       |
| ----- | ----------------- | --- | ----- | --- | ---------------------------------------------------------- | -------- | ------- | -------------------------------------------------------- | ----- |
|       | Human/Other       | Elf | Dwarf | Orc | Gnome                                                      | Illithid | Centaur | Nymph                                                    | Giant |
| Giant | ×1                | ×1  | ×3⁄2  | ×1  | ×3⁄2 if [INT](/wiki/Int "Int") is ≤14 ×4⁄3 if INT is 15-17 | ×10      | ×1      | ×4⁄3 if [CHA](/wiki/Cha "Cha") is ≥15 ×5⁄3 if CHA is <15 | ×3⁄4  |

### Starting equipment

Giants may start with random valuable gems in their inventory. Many roles' normal starting items, primarily pieces of body armor, are also exchanged to accommodate their body size and natural AC so that a given giant is *at least* roughly around the role's usual starting AC.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The differences in starting inventory are as follows:

| Standard item(s)                                                                         | Replacement item(s)                                                                                                                     | Affected roles                                             |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------- |
| [ring mail](/wiki/Ring_mail "Ring mail")                                                 | +0 [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet")                                                                                                      | [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian")                   |
| [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") | [amulet of magic resistance](/wiki/Amulet_of_magic_resistance "Amulet of magic resistance") +0 [low boots](/wiki/Low_boots "Low boots") | [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")                            |
| [splint mail](/wiki/Splint_mail "Splint mail")                                           | [large splint mail](/wiki/Large_splint_mail "Large splint mail")                                                                        | [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")                         |
| [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe")                                                                | +1 [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots")                                                                                          | [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest") |
| [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor")                                     | +0 helmet                                                                                                                               | [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman")                         |
| [jacket](/wiki/Jacket "Jacket")                                                          | +1 low boots                                                                                                                            | [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel")                         |
| [cloak of protection](/wiki/Cloak_of_protection "Cloak of protection")                   | +0 [gauntlets of protection](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_protection "Gauntlets of protection")                                                   | Infidel                                                    |

### Strategy

As most giants are unable to wear most body armor, players should plan their goals, [wishes](/wiki/Wish "Wish") and [ascension kits](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit") accordingly. [Reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") is somewhat more lenient to obtain as a [property](/wiki/Property "Property"), since you can go for an amulet, shield or an artifact you can sacrifice for (such as the highly-desired [Dragonbane](/wiki/Dragonbane#EvilHack "Dragonbane")). Magic resistance is somewhat more difficult, since an amulet is the only non-artifact source.

Strength-boosting comestibles such as [spinach](/wiki/Spinach "Spinach") give giants more strength on average because they can exceed 18/\*\* strength; however, unless playing the Caveman role, giants cannot eat giant corpses due to the [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") and [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") penalties from [cannibalism](/wiki/Cannibalism "Cannibalism"), and alignment record penalties have more gameplay implications in EvilHack.

Most giant players should consider gathering a stack of boulders as soon as possible: multiple thrown boulders can kill various hostile monsters on offense, including stronger opponents, and on defense they can be used to arrange a wall or [boulder fort](/wiki/Boulder_fort "Boulder fort") to block off or constrain monsters on defense; boulders can also be used to create a path through water-blocked areas like the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines"). However, defensive boulder walls are usually best established in advance due to the giant's low speed, and they are far from invincible - a hostile monster with a [wand of striking](/wiki/Wand_of_striking "Wand of striking") can easily destroy a boulder fort; certain monsters can also break through boulders, either with a [digging tool](/wiki/Digging_tool "Digging tool") or through their own power, and boulders also will stop hostile giants or [phasing](/wiki/Phasing "Phasing") monsters. [Sokoban](/index.php?title=Sokoban_\(EvilHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Sokoban (EvilHack) (page does not exist)") and random boulder rooms are usually good sources of boulders, and digging monsters will often leave behind boulders while moving around the level.

## NetHack Fourk

### Racial benefits and restrictions

Giants can pick up and throw boulders, but their size prevents them from wearing most normal armor. They move at half-speed and have a heightened attribute cap for strength, but significantly lower caps for every other attribute.

## SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), the giant is inherited as a playable race from the gigant of [Slash'EM Extended](/wiki/Slash%27EM_Extended "Slash'EM Extended"). They can be of any alignment, and can be played as [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict"), [Diver](/wiki/Diver "Diver"), [Firefighter](/wiki/Firefighter "Firefighter"), [Flame Mage](/wiki/Flame_Mage "Flame Mage"), [Gladiator](/wiki/Gladiator "Gladiator"), [Lunatic](/wiki/Lunatic "Lunatic"), [Paladin](/wiki/Paladin_\(role\) "Paladin (role)"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Undead Slayer](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer"), [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie"), [Warrior](/wiki/Warrior_\(role\) "Warrior (role)"), or [Zookeeper](/wiki/Zookeeper "Zookeeper").

[Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome_\(monster_attribute\) "Gnome (monster attribute)") and [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") are always hostile towards giant heroes.

### Racial benefits and restrictions

Giants gain [fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance") at [XL](/wiki/XL "XL") 10, [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance") at 15, and [shock resistance](/wiki/Shock_resistance "Shock resistance") at 20.

With the exception of Cavepeople, giant heroes can always raise their [two weapon combat](/wiki/Two_weapon_combat "Two weapon combat") and [two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword") skills to a minimum of Skilled.

#### Attribute caps

| Character [Race](/wiki/Race "Race") | [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") |
| ----------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Giant                               | 25                                    | 15                                       | 20                                                | 17                                                | 17                              | 16                                    |

## References

2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [EvilHack 0.7.0 u\_init.c, line 271](https://github.com/k21971/EvilHack/blob/0.7.1/src/u_init.c#L271)

Giant (starting race)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

The giant is a playable race that first appears in GruntHack, and is also present in NetHack Fourk, SliceHack, SlashTHEM, EvilHack, and Hack'EM. Most implementations give them traits similar to the non-playable giants encountered in vanilla NetHack, such as heightened strength caps, lower speed, and the ability to freely pick up and carry boulders.

Fortunately, the Sokoban prize armor is tailored so that player characters of all species can use them, including giants. Giants' size and strength grant additional advantages elsewhere, however: in addition to making strength-based actions easier, giants excel in combat with their [[bare hands]] and with [[club]]s - they have a greater chance of stunning an opponent with a club or punch, and can shatter a foe's wielded weapon with almost any wielded weapon of their own. Giants can also wield [[two-handed weapon]]s in one hand, and may even [[twoweapon]] them as well. The [[woolly mammoth]] is the sole available steed for giants, but is a suitably powerful choice for a pet in its own right, and is capable of steamrolling several late-game monsters. ====Attribute caps==== {| class="prettytable" !| Character

+0 [[low boots]] || [[Wizard]] |- | [[splint mail]] || [[large splint mail]] || [[Samurai]] |- | [[robe]] || +1 [[high boots]] || [[Monk]], [[Priest]] |- | [[leather armor]] || +0 helmet || [[Caveman]] |- | [[jacket]] || +1 low boots || [[Infidel]] |- | [[cloak of protection]] || +0 [[gauntlets of protection]]|| Infidel |} ===Strategy=== As most giants are unable to wear most body armor, players should plan their goals, [[wish]]es and [[ascension kit]]s accordingly. [[Reflection]] is somewhat more lenient to obtain as a [[property]], since you can go for an amulet, shield or an artifact you can sacrifice for (such as the highly-desired [[Dragonbane#EvilHack|Dragonbane]]). Magic resistance is somewhat more difficult, since an amulet is the only non-artifact source. Strength-boosting comestibles such as [[spinach]] give giants more strength on average because they can exceed 18/** strength; however, unless playing the Caveman role, giants cannot eat giant corpses due to the [[Luck]] and [[alignment record]] penalties from [[cannibalism]], and alignment record penalties have more gameplay implications in EvilHack. Most giant players should consider gathering a stack of boulders as soon as possible: multiple thrown boulders can kill various hostile monsters on offense, including stronger opponents, and on defense they can be used to arrange a wall or [[boulder fort]] to block off or constrain monsters on defense; boulders can also be used to create a path through water-blocked areas like the [[Gnomish Mines]]. However, defensive boulder walls are usually best established in advance due to the giant's low speed, and they are far from invincible - a hostile monster with a [[wand of striking]] can easily destroy a boulder fort; certain monsters can also break through boulders, either with a [[digging tool]] or through their own power, and boulders also will stop hostile giants or [[phasing]] monsters. [[Sokoban (EvilHack)|Sokoban]] and random boulder rooms are usually good sources of boulders, and digging monsters will often leave behind boulders while moving around the level. ==NetHack Fourk== ===Racial benefits and restrictions=== Giants can pick up and throw boulders, but their size prevents them from wearing most normal armor. They move at half-speed and have a heightened attribute cap for strength, but significantly lower caps for every other attribute. ==SlashTHEM== In [[SlashTHEM]], the giant is inherited as a playable race from the gigant of [[Slash'EM Extended]]. They can be of any alignment, and can be played as [[Barbarian]], [[Caveman]], [[Convict]], [[Diver]], [[Firefighter]], [[Flame Mage]], [[Gladiator]], [[Lunatic]], [[Paladin (role)|Paladin]], [[Priest]], [[Ranger]], [[Undead Slayer]], [[Valkyrie]], [[Warrior (role)|Warrior]], or [[Zookeeper]]. [[Gnome (monster attribute)|Gnomes]] and [[Dwarf (monster attribute)|dwarves]] are always hostile towards giant heroes. ===Racial benefits and restrictions=== Giants gain [[fire resistance]] at [[XL]] 10, [[cold resistance]] at 15, and [[shock resistance]] at 20.
